summary: In this chapter, Sarah Knight introduces the concept of categorizing our worries using a humorous analogy of tropical cyclones. She explains how anxiety often feels like brewing catastrophes, but we have control over these 'shitclones'. By assessing the likelihood of each worry, we can prevent unnecessary panic. Knight encourages readers to use logic as a soothing tool to reduce anxiety. Realizing that many of our fears are unfounded can liberate us from needless stress.

slides.section_title: Introducing the Concept of Worry Categories
slides.section_body: Every worry can be categorized like a weather system, from minor annoyances to major catastrophes. Using this framework, we can assess which worries actually deserve our attention. This helps us focus on what truly matters rather than spinning into anxiety. The analogy of tropical cyclones illustrates how we can monitor our worries and prepare for them.
slides.quote: ‘Each what-if is like a tropical cyclone brewing on the radar screen of your mind.’

slides.section_body: Not all worries turn into full-blown shitstorms. Some are merely 'Category 1' — likely to fizzle out without any impact. Recognizing the levels of our worries helps us manage them effectively. This realization can reduce the power that these anxieties have over our lives.
slides.quote: ‘Mulling the likelihood of a potential shitstorm actually coming to pass is a useful exercise.’

slides.section_body: Consulting your own 'probometer' allows you to evaluate the reality of your situations. This helps ground your thoughts and assess how true your fears are. Often, we are facing fears that have very low probabilities of occurring. Logic can pull us back from the edge of panic.
slides.quote: ‘Consulting your probometer helps you focus on the reality of your situation.’

slides.section_body: Just like unrealistic 'after' photos in advertisements, many of our fears are exaggerated by our minds. We tend to fall for the tricks our imagination plays on us. By recognizing this, we can better combat the unnecessary anxiety built upon mistaken beliefs.
slides.quote: ‘Stop falling for that shit, will ya?’

slides.section_body: When we begin to categorize our worries, it becomes evident that many do not warrant our time. This realization can be liberating. The more we practice this skill, the quicker we can dismiss minor worries that do not affect our life significantly.
slides.quote: ‘You'll begin to realize you don’t have nearly as much to worry about as you thought you did.’

slides.section_body: Logic can serve as an anchor in turbulent moments of anxiety. Embracing logical thinking reduces emotional turbulence and allows for clearer decision-making. Logic reassures us that many of our fears are unfounded and can keep the 'shitclones' from escalating.

When faced with a what-if situation, try to categorize it based on its severity. This can help determine if you should invest emotional energy in it. Most of the time, these scenarios are not worth your attention.
slides.quote: ‘Total Cat. One. Not worth worrying about.’

slides.section_body: Changing how you view potential disasters can minimize their emotional impact. The less you dwell on what could go wrong, the less power these thoughts hold over you. A shift in perspective can lead to a more peaceful and satisfying life.
slides.quote: ‘Category Two, no need to spend those freakout funds quite yet.’

slides.section_body: Using humor to address our fears can significantly reduce their weight. Laughing at our anxieties presents them as less daunting and allows us to regain control. It's an effective tool for defusing tension and fostering a healthier mindset.

Ultimately, we have the power to direct our thoughts and emotions. By employing logic and categorizing our worries effectively, we can live more balanced lives. This practice instills a sense of control and reduces unnecessary stress.
slides.quote: ‘You don’t have to face it all at once, one step at a time.’
